div.p: Skhirat is the name for a group of small villages (duwwāṛ, pl. dwāwīr), which are situated in the southwest of the Kasserine Governorate very close to the Algerian border. The name ṣxīṛāt (“rocks”) refers to stones generated by volcanic activity in the region, which causes magma to emerge from the earth. There is a place called iṣ-ṣxīṛa s-sōda (“the black rock”) which constitutes the border between Skhirat and Umm Ali. The area’s flora is characterised by halfah grass (il-ḥalfa) and oleander (id-difla). Rivers dried out due to missing rain, like the wǟd l-ⁱkbīr, also called ⁱṛmāda, on the border to Algeria, which was used by semi-nomads to gain drinking water.

The region of today’s Skhirat used to be very poor. According to local sources, there are seven tribal groups settling in the area, among them Ūlǟd Maṛzūg, il-Lṭāyfīya, Ūlǟd Fǟraḥ, Ūlǟd Ibṛāhīm, Ūlǟd Sīdi ʕBīd and Ūlǟd Sī Tlīl. As the earth is dry and infertile, its inhabitants used to maintain a seminomadic lifestyle, living in tents (ʕišša, pl. ʕšūš). In summer, they used to travel to l-ⁱfrīgya, a geographical term subsuming approximately the governorates of Beja, Jendouba and Kef, to harvest wheat and barley in order to receive a tenth of the total harvest (il-ʕᵘšuṛ). This region was called dāṛ iṣ-ṣīf. Then they returned to harvest the cactus figs (hindi) in Sbeitla, Foussana and Kasserine – for consumption and to feed their camels, but also to dry them in order to conserve them for the winter. This they called dāṛ il-hindi. There was also the dāṛ it-tamṛ at the Chott el Djerid, where they used to collect dates (tamṛ). In years of drought, they took their herds further south to pasture in the region of Metlaoui, Moulares, Redeyef and Oued el Jemel situated in today’s governorate of Gafsa, and stayed there until the next spring.

Traditional life changed with the establishment of the first school in the area. The first generations that received higher education contributed to the development of the region by building irrigation systems and houses, and started to grow different crops like olive, almond and pistachio trees. Over the course of time, electricity and water supply was introduced, shops opened and streets were paved.
To the best of our knowledge hitherto no research has been done on the dialect of Skhirat, however this dialect is linguistically investigated within the TUNOCENT project.
